007 * Visit https://imagingbook.com for additional details.
008 ******************************************************************************/
009package imagingbook.common.filter.generic;
010
011import imagingbook.common.image.PixelPack;
012
013/**
014 * This (abstract) class represents a generic vector filter whose pixel-operation is x/y-separable. It is similar to
015 * {@link GenericFilterVector} but requires two methods to be implemented by concrete sub-classes:
016 * {@link #doPixelX(PixelPack, int, int)} and {@link #doPixelY(PixelPack, int, int)} for the x- and y-pass,
017 * respectively, which are invoked in exactly this order. The remaining filter mechanics including out-of-bounds
018 * coordinate handling, multiple passes and data copying are handled by this class and its super-class (see
019 * {@link GenericFilter}).
020 */
021public abstract class GenericFilterVectorSeparable extends GenericFilter { // GenericFilterVector
022        
023        private int iter = 0;
024        private int iterMax = 1;        // for progress reporting only
025        
026        @Override 
027        protected void runPass(PixelPack source, PixelPack target) {
028                final int width = source.getWidth();
029                final int height = source.getHeight();
030                iterMax = width * height * 2;
031                iter = 0;
032                
033                // X-part
034                //IJ.log("X-part +++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++");
035                for (int v = 0; v < height; v++) {
036                        for (int u = 0; u < width; u++) {
037                                target.setPix(u, v, doPixelX(source, u, v)); // single pixel operation
038                                iter++;
039                        }
040                }
041                
042                target.copyTo(source);
043                
044                // Y-part
045                //IJ.log("Y-part +++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++");
046                for (int v = 0; v < height; v++) {
047                        for (int u = 0; u < width; u++) {
048                                target.setPix(u, v, doPixelY(source, u, v)); // single pixel operation
049                                iter++;
050                        }
051                }
052                iter = 0;
053        }
054        
055        // ------------------------------------------------------------------------
056
057        /**
058         * Applies a 1D filter operation in x-direction.
059         * This method must be implemented by concrete sub-classes.
060         * This method is invoked before {@link #doPixelY(PixelPack, int, int)}.
061         * The source data are passed as a {@link PixelPack} container, which
062         * holds the vector values of all image components.
063         * The method {@link PixelPack#getPix(int, int)} should be used to read
064         * individual pixel vectors. These data should not be modified but
065         * the (float[]) result of the single-pixel calculation must be returned.
066         * Implementations are free to return the same float-array at each invocation,
067         * i.e., there is no need to allocate a new array every time.
068         * 
069         * @param source the scalar-valued data for a single image component
070         * @param u the current x-position
071         * @param v the current y-position
072         * @return the result of the filter calculation for this pixel
073         */
074        protected abstract float[] doPixelX(PixelPack source, int u, int v);
075
076        /**
077         * Applies a 1D filter operation in y-direction.
078         * This method must be implemented by concrete sub-classes.
079         * This method is invoked after {@link #doPixelX(PixelPack, int, int)}.
080         * The source data are passed as a {@link PixelPack} container, which
081         * holds the vector values of all image components.
082         * The method {@link PixelPack#getPix(int, int)} should be used to read
083         * individual pixel vectors. These data should not be modified but
084         * the (float[]) result of the single-pixel calculation must be returned.
085         * Implementations are free to return the same float-array at each invocation,
086         * i.e., there is no need to allocate a new array every time.
087         * 
088         * @param source the scalar-valued data for a single image component
089         * @param u the current x-position
090         * @param v the current y-position
091         * @return the result of the filter calculation for this pixel
092         */
093        protected abstract float[] doPixelY(PixelPack source, int u, int v);
094        
095        // ------------------------------------------------------------------------
096
097        @Override
098        protected final double reportProgress(double subProgress) {
099                double localProgress = (double) iter /iterMax;
100                //System.out.println("GenericFilterVector: reportProgress() - returning " + localProgress);
101                return super.reportProgress(localProgress);
102        }
103        
104}
